admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Treasury Development
            Project for Russian Federation were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory; risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible; Bank performance was satisfactory and borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            includes: client ownership and strong strategic leadership
            on the beneficiary side is a key to success of institutional
            development projects. Continuity of the core team working on
            the project, both from the Bank side and the government
            side, is very important for the success of a project. While
            designing the project, wider involvement of counterparts
            involved in management of public finances should be ensured
            in order to explore various available options for a good
            project. It is essential to pay close attention at the
            design stage to the political economy context of the
            country. Simple design and focus on the core functionality
            of the treasury system are highly appropriate for initial
            stage of implementation of public Financial Management
            Information Systems (FMIS). Frequent changes in legislation
            will adversely affect the momentum of implementation of any
            project that supports automation of procedures derived from
            that legislation. Very close monitoring of procurement
            process by the project team and quick reaction to each
            potential problem or bottleneck with finding appropriate and
            mutually acceptable solution, will work strongly for the
            smooth implementation of the project and its overall success.
